evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical baseline period prior to preliminary analysis on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical baseline is resistant to defeaters, as alternative explanations such as equipment failure or external interference have been ruled out.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical baseline, including lapses in information exchange and coordination protocols.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical baseline period prior to preliminary analysis on 12-25.

assumptions: The observed events reflect communication/coordination breakdown rather than solely procedural deviation
The historical baseline period includes these events as relevant to the claim
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than communication

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 documents communication and coordination events among crew and tug operators, showing a breakdown in coordination as the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit a barrier, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical baseline, including lapses in information exchange and coordination protocols.

No contradictory evidence from other sources
defeaters: If evidence showed flawless communication or procedural adherence without coordination lapses

node.statement: The environmental/marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t0_prelim dataset.

The continued movement beyond TRP despite engine idle indicates a marking or environmental deficiency rather than procedural or mechanical causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed the markings were adequate and visible, or if mechanical faults were verified, the environmental deficiency claim would be weakened.
If communication or procedural errors fully explained the event without marking issues, the claim would be less supported.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
